content.description: Climb a nice 5.10 start, beginning with an interesting move before the first clip. Approach the Wanker Rail with a devious sequence of hand switches on the arete, avoiding the urge to pull up and right into Man For the Job. This section may feel contrived, but the Rail needed to be climbed. Clip the crux bolt and stay low on good feet and small crimps, then creep up left on the Wanker Rail with some hidden holds way out left. Pimp the rail past another bolt to a ledge, finish up the slabby dihedral.
content.location: Starts just left of Stepchild.

content.description: A difficult boulder problem crux past two bolts in an open dihedral leads to a great crack with good but tricky protection.
content.location: Between Keepin' It Real and Red Dream. Look for two bolts.

content.description: A short warm-up on gorgeous stone. A water streaked slab followed by a stem dihedral. Would be 3 or 4 stars if it were twice as long.
content.location: Starts from a nice shady terrace just up and right of Oaksterdam and Red Dream.

content.description: A stepped route with multiple cruxes on beautiful rock. Starts with three, steep slab, boulder problem steps followed by a pretty stemming dihedral with a couple steps of it's own.
content.location: Starts off little grassy terrace with 2 small pine trees. Look for bolts going up a black streak that originates in a dihedral above.

content.description: Climb up and over a crimpy face to a slab.  At the top of the slab lies an obtuse overhanging dihedral marked by spaced out gastons and tips pods. Power through this section to another great rest. Finish up a orange refrigerator block side-pulling away.
content.location: To the right of fir real and left of wanker rail.

content.description: Simply put.  This route is SICK! The Line shares the start of Jug a Low.  Instead of continuing straight up bust right into stellar looking overhung crack.  Enjoy hand friendly rock, fantastic holds and a whole lot of pump up the steep crack.  Keep moving until you reach the final stem when the crack becomes less steep.  The final feet of the climb rely on stemming and power to pull the finishing moves topping out the cliff.
content.location: in the main amphitheater, shares start with Jug a Low.

content.description: A good sport route that follows a seam and beautiful rock through three distinct cruxes.
content.protection: bolts - use a long runner on the 1st bolt.
content.location: This route starts next to a pointy boulder lying next to the wall. Look for the pretty, steep crack up high with the prominent water streak on the face to the right. This route has a cruxy mantle past the 2nd bolt that is pretty easy to identify.

content.description: An unfinished, open project featuring a severe unclimbed crux in the beginning of the dihedral followed by incredible hard stemming to the anchor. This climb is not yet bolted because no one has been able to do the crux section.
content.location: Located just behind a large pine tree uphill of Jug a Low.

content.description: A pretty line up a varied crack system. Funky off the deck to a hand crack crux, then a little more burl at the end. A bit sharp at times. Tape is recommended for maximum enjoyment.
content.protection: Standard rack. No anchor. Walk off for now.
content.location: Upper right side of the wall starting in a nice little terraced alcove.

content.description: Great sport climb up a red arete. A must do for the area.
content.location: Just right of Up the 9.

content.description: A short, black and tan arete accessed by a few bolts of easier climbing. Miniscule, sharp holds define the crux. Recently broken - a new ascent is needed to confirm a grade.
content.location: Just right of Stepchild and shares the first bolt. Runout, but 5.0, to second bolt.

content.description: Praylord is an alternate finish to jesus jugs.  Climb jesus jugs until you can bust up and out of the dihedral using the crack in the left wall.  Continue up and left into the obvious finned wide crack.
content.location: located in the pigmy cracks area.  shares same start as jesus jugs.

content.description: Crack with small pine tree in the start leads to a nice fingercrack finish.
content.protection: Rack with nuts. No anchor yet. Walk off or find a nearby anchor.
content.location: Just right of Red Dream.

content.description: Good fun climbing leads around an offset dihedral, followed by a steep featured headwall with a seam splitting the middle. Just when you think  you have found a moderate... a stinger of a crux guards the chains. Good route.
content.location: Just up and right of Freedom of the Hills. Starts next to a large rotten pine tree stump.

content.description: Varied crack climb with no anchor. Scramble down off right.
content.location: 25 feet right of Sun Shower.

content.description: Man for the Job shares the Wanker Rail start, with a 5.10 move before the first bolt. *****If you can't figure out how to get on the Wanker Rail before bailing to the ledge, then Man For the Job allows you to still make it to the top and to an anchor so you can get your draws down. And that's about it.***** After the third bolt, climb up to the good stance and follow the arete for a few moves. Gain a ledge and do a little boulder problem - the crux - to another ledge. Plug in a small cam or two and finish on steep, juggy crack features. This route is a hodgepodge of features separated by slabby ledges that really needed a clean, straight, uncomplicated  rope line to connect them and balance out the chaotic nature of the line. Geek out!
content.protection: 6 bolts and a .4 and/or .5 camalot for the ending. The last bolt is reachy to clip, but would be useless if placed lower. Really short folks may want to have a pre-hung draw for their ascent, or bring a stiff quick draw with a loose gate.
content.location: Shares start with Wanker Rail, just left of Stepchild.

content.description: Trad climb that passes a bolt about half way up. A little chossy in the final crack section. No anchor yet.
content.location: Just right of Riot Act...look for single bolt in black rock.

content.description: David kept it real going for the onsight F.A. He didn't make it, but confirmed the need for bolts for the entire route. Cool slab leads to steeper rock and then the crux - a powerful long reach over the bulge followed by an insecure pinch move. Excellent stemming up the final dihedral. This one requires finesse and power.
content.location: Starts one terrace up from Stepchild etc. Pull the direct boulder problem start or just climb the slab by traversing in from the right. 1st bolt at about 25 feet.

content.description: A wandering trad pitch featuring a large roof at the top.
content.location: Jug a Low is on the first good section of wall as you arrive at the area. Look for the obvious roof crack at 60 feet that traverses left then up to an anchor.

content.description: Joycone begins with some cool moves through a short dihedral and finishes on a very aesthetic arete feature - the Joycone. The arete section is short, but hosts some of the best holds and moves at the cliff. Be sure to take in the view while topping out.
content.location: The pretty arete just to the left of Sunshower.

content.description: This route might be the friendliest dacite crack around. The route begins with 9 ft. Of jug pulling on a face which brings you to the beautiful hand crack in the dihedral. As you climb up the ever widening crack enjoy the awesome jams and jugs. Pull up onto the block and place a few interesting pieces before busting the crux move up the left leaning crack. Finish by topping out.
content.location: Pigmy cracks area. Lowest sector of routes at oaklands. Look up left as you walk up the trail. It's the obvious clean splinter dihedral.

content.description: A good, long, moderate line with quality rock and a surprising steep finish on great holds.
content.location: Starts up and right of All Natural under a large pine tree.

content.description: Starts at a little fir tree below the obvious right facing overhanging corner.  Crank straight up next to the tree through the low 11 stuff, then over a little butt puckering slab bulge to the base of the corner.  Burl down or finess your way up the good holds throught the corner and end at a golden jug.  Now feel good. Clip the last bolt and do a couple 7ish hand jams to the anchors.  Another quality addition to this stacked section of Oaklands.
content.location: Located in the upper area of Oaklands right of Runaway Train and Left of Wanker Rail.

content.description: A route with Jackel and Hyde demeanor. Begin up easy (Jackel) hand crack until it vanishes leaving a steep headwall.  The next three bolts contain the crux (Hyde). Move up good edges until you can reach the calcified holds that lead to a great rest in a giant pocket. Finish the route by firing out overhanging jugs (Jackel) and into the finishing crack to the anchors.
content.location: On the far right side of the wall

content.description: Dish Network is all about a large dish set 30 feet off the ground on a steep bulge. A great section of steep pulling off the ground leads to a ledge and the Dish above. 2 or 3 seconds of bouldering power gets you past the dish. From a ledge climb up another section of rock past 2 bolts to the anchor.
content.location: Far right side of the cliff. Look for the Dish.

content.description: Crazy Fool follows a curving seam past a distinct crux in the middle. A neat slabby section in the start delivers you to a stance with some sweet underclings below the crux. Unlock the sequence and enjoy some fun climbing to the anchor.
content.location: Just downhill and left of Ride the Snake.

content.description: Easy start can be soloed or gear can be found. Above the break climb thin technical crimps over the bulge.  Continue up face steeper finish.
content.protection: Bolts and maybe a cam down low
content.location: Right of sun shower

content.description: Climbs the dihedral to the right of Quannum arete and finishes at the same anchor. Excellent technical stemming through the dihedral that never lets up. Be sure to stretch.
content.location: Same start as Quannum, but move right and clip the control bolt at the start of the dihedral.

content.description: An obvious right leaning roof of perfect hand jams and exciting 5.8 footwork. Once you turn the corner it is some wide crack and jugs to the top.
content.protection: Single set + an extra #2 and a #4optional
content.location: From the base of Jesus Jugs scramble up and left through an interesting chimney.  There is an nice belay right below the money corner.  You can build an anchor and use it for the three routes in this spot then clean it and walk off left.

content.description: The Chalk Troll is a classic boulder problem located in a cave along the base of the wall. Start sitting down and climb out the bulging overhang on excellent pinches. A difficult long move guards the final jug. Top out then down climb back to the jug and drop off. So far, this is the most difficult climb completed at Oaklands.
content.protection: At least two pads are needed. I'd prefer about 5 for the last move.
content.location: Located in a bouldering cave along the base of the wall, about 5 minutes below the main section of cliff. Chalk Troll climbs out the left side of the cave, starting below the obvious scrotum-like bulge.

content.description: Same start as Ride the Snake, but moves right after the initial crux and follows the crack in the middle of a large curving black streak. One bolt links crack features. After a technical section past the bolt, climb perfect steep hands to the anchor. A little sharp...may want to tape.
content.protection: Standard Rack. Save #1s and #2s for the ending. One bolt. Chain anchor.
content.location: Same start as Riding the Snake.

content.description: CURRENTLY A TOP ROPE. YET TO BE BOLTED. Start up the dihedral till you can stand on the ledge below the small roof. Move out the roof to the one hold in the dihedral. Get creative with your smearing knee/body barring to reach the semi cleaned vertical seam. Get a knee bar and rest on the jug. Here move right to the big pocket out right. Continue up bulge on cool side pulls till you can throw for the big flat edges. This marks the end of the hard. Move up last ten feet of cool holds to finish.
content.location: To the right of oak wild

content.description: Ball Sports climbs a 30 foot dihedral set 35 feet off the deck. Climb dirty, slabby crack to a ledge at the base of the corner, or climb the first 4 bolts of All Natural. Place some good directionals and climb 5.10 up to the crux - a body stem off a palm smear. Burly crux moves with tricky pro. Props to John Crawley for getting this one done with fearless determination.
content.protection: Small cams up to #1, nuts, tiny aliens may be useful for the finish
content.location: Striking dihedral just left of All Natural.

content.description: 4 bolts up a neat slab lead to a ledge and a beautiful red and green face set between two clean aretes. Begin on the left arete from a block resting on the ledge and climb up and right, finishing in the cool hanging dihedral that forms high on the face. Excellent holds and movement on this one. Another must do for the area.
content.location: Just right of Ball Sports dihedral.

content.description: Oaklands is a 60-80 foot, south facing, dacite cliff on the western side of Elden. The area is named after the abundant oak trees that grow along the south facing slope of the gully. The routes follow visually pleasing cracks, seams, dihedrals and aretes. There are some pure cracks and several sport climbs, with a few mixed routes as well. Like other dacite areas the climbing is vertical, technical, and often bouldery with generally small, heavily textured, holds. Oaklands is a warm, south facing cliff, so the cooler months of fall offer the best climbing conditions.
